title: Virgin Money’s shares recover losses from Budget tax shock
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Tue, Jul 28, 2015, 16:45 BST - UK Markets closed Virgin Money’s shares recover losses from Budget tax shock By Tim Wallace | Telegraph – 6 minutes ago 18.05 +0.24 
Challenger banks were hit hard by the surprise 8pc additional tax announced by the Chancellor this month, but Virgin's stock has bounced almost all the way back 
Virgin Money’s share price soared on Tuesday following unexpectedly strong financial results, regaining almost all of the ground the stock lost when the Chancellor announced a new tax on banks in his emergency Budget . 
The challenger bank’s shares jumped by as much as 13.5pc as it reported surging profits and healthy mortgage growth, taking the stock to 425p, almost back to its pre-Budget 434p level. 
Changes to the way buy-to-let mortgage borrowers can offset interest payments also rocked the sector, leading to fears the number of customers would drop. 
“The Budget’s consequences for buy-to-let lending and the tax charge, and the overall stock market position, have meant shares were in a bit of the doldrums, and we had not been able to say anything to change it,” said Virgin Money’s chief executive Jayne-Anne Gadhia . 
“Now (NYSE: DNOW - news ) , we’re able to show the performance we’ve achieved and our expectations for the future, and that has helped markets see that actually the BTL position has a very limited impact on us, and that the surcharge might delay our path to material returns but it is not going to stop us getting there. As a consequence I hope it has given the market new confidence we’re going to hit our targets.” 
Virgin Money's share price soared on Tuesday 
Ms Gadhia is lobbying the Treasury behind closed doors in a bid to tweak the tax. 
“We have spoken to HM Treasury, but the right way to talk about this is in private. We will see what happens when the Finance Bill becomes the Finance Act (Frankfurt: 0LW.F - news ) ,” Ms Gadhia said. 
Shawbrook Bank is also lobbying the Chancellor privately in an effort to get him to change the tax. 
“The tax position is something we were naturally disappointed by, but we have not been vocal on it. We will deal with these matters behind closed doors,” said the challenger bank’s interim chief executive Tom Woods. 
It follows TSB chief Paul Pester’s request last week that the threshold for paying the tax should be raised from £25m to £250m, arguing the levy will reduce the amount of funds available for small banks to invest and grow. Secure Trust Bank’s chief Paul Lynam is also pushing for small lenders to be excluded from the tax. 
"The tax kicks in at £25m of profits, and we’ve made our views clear to the Treasury that we would love to see that level raised a bit," said Mr Pester. "It takes a big chunk off our profits, it makes it more difficult for us to invest to grow, and to bring more competition to the UK market.”
